awd_titl_txt: Transfer-to-Excellence (TTE) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States is facing a severe deficit of scientists and engineers in the upcoming decades. One of the main reasons is the lack of diversity of students in STEM disciplines. Typically, students attracted by STEM majors are primarily male and come from non-Hispanic white or Asian populations. The need for appealing to and retaining students coming from non-traditional backgrounds is evident, given the shifts in the U.S. population demographics. As a way to address this issue, the Transfer-to-Excellence Research Experiences for Undergraduates (TTE REU) program of the University of California, Berkeley (UC Berkeley) supports retention in STEM fields by offering hands-on research opportunities in nanotechnology, biotechnology, and robotics to increase the confidence and persistence of community college students in their pursuit of science and engineering education and ultimately technical careers. The nine-week program brings 10 students per year from California Community Colleges (CCC), the largest community college system in the U.S., to UC Berkeley, where engineering faculty will host students in their world-class research laboratories and mentor them in their own research projects. These schools will provide a diverse pool of talented future researchers, including low-income, first-generation, and/or underrepresented minority community college students, who might not otherwise have the resources or opportunities to pursue careers in research. Students will be engaged in leading-edge engineering research projects, including nanotechnology, energy-efficient electronics, biotechnology, sustainable engineering, body-centered sensors, mechatronics, greenhouse gas research, and optoelectronics. 

The renewal TTE REU program is a comprehensive summer research program that provides: 1) challenging research projects in leading edge engineering research laboratories; 2) counseling to prepare students to transfer to competitive four-year colleges/universities in science and engineering majors; 3) enrichment activities to build students' confidence to continue in science and engineering; and 4) exposure to the diversity of professional career opportunities that apply science and engineering training. The TTE program partners with advisors of Berkeley's Transfer Alliance Project to support its community college participants for another academic year following their research experience as the participants seek to transfer to a baccalaureate program. The main objectives of this renewal program are increasing 1) the number of underrepresented students who will seek and receive a baccalaureate degree in STEM and 2) the diversity of students pursuing graduate degrees in STEM disciplines. To accomplish these objectives, this REU Site will bring together the Center for E3S, UC Berkeley Transfer Alliance Project (TAP), and UC Berkeley engineering faculty. TAP will be a collaborator to provide academic advising and enrichment programs that prepare community colleges students to be competitive applicants to four-year colleges. Each TTE REU participant will be paired with a faculty member and a graduate student or postdoc, who will guide the student in independent research activities, at laboratory meetings, and through one-on-one mentoring meetings. TTE REU participants will also participate in academic and professional development activities to prepare for a baccalaureate degree and career in science and engineering. In addition, all TTE REU participants will be enrolled in a new online mentorship program after their summer research stay ends. This online program will enable a long-term, sustained and formalized mentoring relationship with all participants with the goal of retaining and further stimulating the students' interest in graduate school.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
Advancing California Community College Students through Engineering Research REU Site

Project Outcomes Report

 

The “Advancing California Community College Students through Engineering Research” REU site is a multi-disciplinary summer undergraduate research program at the University of California, Berkeley. This program has provided cutting-edge research opportunities for California community college students in science or engineering, with a special focus on women, underrepresented minorities, veterans, students with disabilities, and those that are first-generation college students.

 

For nine weeks, each participant is paired with two mentors from their respective research area: a faculty member and a graduate student or postdoc. The mentors guide the student in independent research activities, at group/laboratory meetings, and through one-on-one mentoring meetings. Outside of their independent research, research interns are trained on research protocol, laboratory safety, and scientific ethics. They also participate in academic and professional development activities to prepare for transfer, baccalaureate education, graduate school, and careers in science and engineering. The REU Site collaborates with the Transfer Alliance Program (TAP), which provides individualized academic advising and enrichment programs to prepare community college students to be competitive applicants to four-year universities. Research interns continue to participate in the TAP program upon their return to community college.

 

Broader Impact

This REU targets a population of students who may lack resources or exposure to science and engineering opportunities but have the intellectual capability to pursue science and engineering degrees. In recruitment, our goal has been to attract a significant number of students from underrepresented groups. This is done through targeted recruitment outreach and through our partnership with an organization that primarily serves underrepresented populations—Mathematics Engineering Science Achievement (MESA).

 

From 2015 to 2018, the REU site provided research experience, technical training, professional development opportunities, mentorship and transfer advising to 53 California community college students. These participants were: 34% female, 26.4% underrepresented ethnic/racial minority (URM), and 51% first generation college students.

 

The 2015-2018 cohorts boast a 92.4% transfer rate to a four-year university to pursue a STEM degree. 83% have transferred to the University of California (UC) system, 45.3% of which transferred to the University of California, Berkeley, and 8% transferred directly into graduate programs at a University of California campus. Additionally, 7.5% transferred to California State University campuses and 2% transferred to a private four-year university within California.

 

Intellectual Merit

The focus of this REU Site was to increase scientific and engineering knowledge and skills of California community college students through hands-on research in nanotechnology, robotics, and biotechnology. The program has hosted 33 participants from 22 different community colleges. This accounts for 19.3% of all community colleges statewide.  Each student worked independently on research projects supervised by a faculty member and graduate student or postdoc mentor. Collectively, the 33 independent projects of the REU program have been advised by 16 faculty mentors and 29 graduate student or post-doc mentors. Importantly, most of the faculty mentors have returned each year because they enjoy hosting these students.

 

Comprehensive Evaluation: The REU is evaluated by an external evaluator. Research interns and their mentors are surveyed before, during, and after their participation and participate in an exit interview. All measures (self-reported and observed) indicate positive and formative experiences for the research interns and their mentors.


Publications and Presentations: This REU has served as a model that has been replicated at other baccalaureate universities wishing to provide more opportunity to community college students. During the course of the grant, program faculty and staff have authored five publications on the best practices and evaluation results for the REU Site. One was published in the Community College Journal of Research and Practice and the remaining four have been in the Proceedings of the American Society for Engineering Education Annual Conference and Exposition. Research interns are also encouraged to share their research findings and are given the option to apply for funding to present at conferences. Of the 2015-2018 cohorts, 14 research interns have presented their research at the Annual Conference for the Society for Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science. Additionally, participants have presented their research at the National Council on Undergraduate Research REU symposium (4 students), National Society of Black Engineers (1 student), and the National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (1 student).

 

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2024
Modified by: Jeffrey Bokor
